P.title: Will the United States sign a Treaty on the Prohibition of Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if, by Jan 1, 2031, the United States Government formally agrees to an international treaty which purports to ban either the possession or the use of Lethal Autonomous Weapons as defined above, and is announced on the U.S. Department of State Office of Treaty Affairs or a mainstream news source or wire service (e.g. AP or New York Times), or NO otherwise.

para_P.title: By the start of 2031, will the U.S. have entered into an international agreement banning lethal autonomous weapons systems?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as YES if the U.S. government has officially joined an international treaty that prohibits the ownership or use of lethal autonomous weapons systems by January 1, 2031, as confirmed by the U.S. Department of State Office of Treaty Affairs or a major news outlet such as the Associated Press or The New York Times. It will resolve as NO if this has not occurred.

P.title: Will US life expectancy at birth for both sexes fall below 75 years before 2040?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2040, US life expectancy at birth (average for both sexes) is less than 75 years, according to the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official statement by any one of those organizations is sufficient to resolve the question

para_P.title: Before 2040, will the average life expectancy at birth in the US for both genders drop below 75 years?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if, from January 1, 2020, to January 1, 2040, the average life expectancy at birth for both males and females in the US falls under 75 years, as reported by the CDC, World Health Organization, or the United Nations. An official declaration by any of these bodies will suffice to settle the question.

P.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event. Statistical significance should be at the 4-sigma or equivalent level.
*(edit 1/1017) November 30 is now a publication date rather than data cutoff date.

para_P.title: By November 30, 2027, will there be a detection of gravitational waves from merging supermassive black holes announced in a peer-reviewed paper?
para_P.body: This question will resolve affirmatively if a peer-reviewed article published by November 30, 2027, confirms the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes, with a statistical significance of 4-sigma or equivalent. Note: November 30 is the publication deadline, not the data cutoff.

P.title: Before 2051, will a meteor cause more injuries than the one that shook Chelyabinsk, Russia in 2013?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In February, 2013, a meteor scorched the Russian skies. EarthSky gives the key details:
A small asteroid with an estimated size of 65 feet... was moving at 12 miles per second (~19 km/sec) when it struck the protective blanket of air around our planet, which did its job and caused the asteroid to explode. The bright, hot explosion took place only about 20 miles (30 km) above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia and carried 20 to 30 times the energy of the Hiroshima atomic bomb. Its shock wave broke windows and knocked down parts of buildings in six Russian cities and caused some 1,500 people to seek medical attention for injuries, mostly from flying glass.
It's only a matter of time before more space rocks as big as (or bigger than) the one that caused the Chelyabinsk Event find their way to Earth.
Before 2051-01-01, will an event cause more injuries than the Chelyabinsk meteor, which injured 1491 people (russian source, wp)? More specifically, will a meteor next injure at least 1492 people? This resolves according to credible media reports, or their median estimate if several are found.

para_P.title: Will a meteor strike before 2051 result in more injuries than the Chelyabinsk event in 2013?
para_P.body: In February 2013, a meteor exploded above Chelyabinsk, Russia, causing injuries to approximately 1,500 people due to its shockwave. The question is whether, before January 1, 2051, a meteor impact will surpass this number of injuries. The resolution will be based on credible media reports or their median estimate if multiple reports are available.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a SpaceX-branded mission successfully lands one or more living human beings on the surface of Mars before 2030. The landing itself of the human crew on Mars must occur before January 1, 2030, 00:00 UTC.
At least one person aboard the lander must survive the landing, however it is not necessary for the person to survive long-term or make a return trip to Earth, nor is it necessary for the mission to intend a return or long-term survival.
A "SpaceX-branded" mission is defined to mean that the SpaceX-associated logos on the spacecraft involved (both the boosters and the Mars-bound craft) have a larger surface area than the logos of any other entity

para_P.title: Will a SpaceX mission successfully achieve a manned landing on Mars by the end of 2029?
para_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2029, a mission under the SpaceX brand has successfully landed at least one living human on Mars. The individual must survive the landing, but not necessarily long-term or return to Earth. The mission must prominently display SpaceX logos, larger than those of any other entity, on all spacecraft involved.

P.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Will Turkey remain a member of NATO without interruption until January 1, 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey maintains uninterrupted membership in NATO from October 1, 2019, to January 1, 2025. It will resolve as No if Turkey is either suspended, expelled, or voluntarily withdraws from NATO at any point before January 1, 2025.
Should NATO be dissolved, or undergo such significant changes in structure or function that Metaculus administrators deem it imprudent to continue this question, it will resolve as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will Próspera at any point before 2035 have at least 10,000 residents?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if Próspera, or the same entity with a different name, at any point before 2035 reports that it has 10,000 or more residents.
For the purposes of this question, e-residents do not count as residents. Only people living on land managed by Próspera do.
If Próspera does not publish population data and such data is not available even upon request, then this question resolves ambiguously

para_P.title: By the year 2035, will the population of Próspera reach or exceed 10,000 people?
para_P.body: This question will be answered affirmatively if, at any time before the year 2035, Próspera or any successor entity under a different name reports having a population of at least 10,000 residents. Only individuals physically residing in the territory managed by Próspera are considered residents; e-residents are excluded. If population data for Próspera is not published or obtainable upon request, the resolution of this question will be considered ambiguous.

P.title: Will Iowa host another "first in the nation" Democratic caucus before 2029?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the modern primary system was established in the United States in 1972, Iowa has had a special status as being the first state in the United States to cast ballots and award delegates for the Presidential campaigns - the coveted "first in the nation" status that brings much media attention (and money) to Iowa.
On February 3, 2020, Iowa held US caucuses. While the Republican caucus was uneventful, the Democratic caucus lead to an unprecedented delay in reporting results, leading to many pundits to declare that the Iowa caucuses would be over. Most notably, David Plouffe, who ran the campaign for Barack Obama, said ”I believe caucuses are dead" on MSNBC.
Will this come true, or are the rumors of the death of this 48 year old tradition greatly exaggerated?
This question will resolve positively if, at least once before the end of 2028, Iowa holds (a) a US Democratic primary election that is both (b) a caucus (as distinct from a primary) and (c) is "first in the nation".
For the purposes of this question, a "caucus" is defined as any system where, (I) rather than going to polls and casting ballots, selectors gather at set locations throughout the state's precincts (e.g., schools, churches, public libraries, casinos) and (II) physically order in publicly-known preference groups and then (III) reallocate according to a viability threshold. (See "walking subcaucus" voting system for details, though any such method meeting I-III will qualify).
A "first in the nation primary event" is defined as a Presidential primary event that awards delegates to the national convention for the purposes of selecting the presidential candidate such that no other such events in that nominating process take place prior or simultaneous with the "first in the nation primary event".
The "US Democratic primary election" refers to a Presidential primary event that selects delegates for the National Convention of the United States Democratic Primary.

para_P.title: Before the end of 2028, will Iowa once again be the initial state to hold a Democratic caucus in the U.S.?
para_P.body: This question will be affirmed if Iowa conducts at least one Democratic caucus before 2029 that also serves as the first delegate-awarding event in the nation for a presidential campaign. The caucus must involve participants gathering at specific locations to form preference groups and reallocate based on viability, distinct from a primary election. The event must precede all other similar national events in the presidential nominating process.

P.title: By 2050, will there be fewer than 400 public 4-year colleges in the US?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there are fewer than 400 public 4-year colleges in the US in any year after 2018, up to and including the 2049-2050 school term, according to NCES. If NCES no longer reports this data, other credible sources may be used. If the school year is no longer over a similar period, the final term can be any period which ends in 2050

para_P.title: Will the number of public four-year institutions in the US drop below 400 by 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if, according to the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) or other credible sources if NCES data is unavailable, the count of public four-year colleges in the US falls below 400 at any point from 2019 to the 2049-2050 academic year. If the academic year structure changes, the relevant term is any that concludes in 2050.

P.title: Will Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster be visited by a spacecraft before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster is an electric sports car that served as the dummy payload for the February 2018 Falcon Heavy test flight and became an artificial satellite of the Sun.
In August 2019, as the Roadster completed its first orbit around the Sun, Musk stated that SpaceX may one day launch a small spacecraft to catch up with the Roadster and take photographs.
Will Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster be visited by any spacecraft before 2050?
The question will resolve positively if any active spacecraft approaches the Tesla Roadster to within a distance of 10,000 kilometers before December 31st of 2049, 23:59 UTC.

para_P.title: Before the year 2050, will any spacecraft rendezvous with Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Launched as a dummy payload during the Falcon Heavy test flight in February 2018, Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster now orbits the Sun as an artificial satellite.
In August 2019, after completing its first solar orbit, Musk suggested that SpaceX might dispatch a small spacecraft to rendezvous with the Roadster and capture images.
The question will be resolved affirmatively if a spacecraft actively approaches the Tesla Roadster to within 10,000 kilometers by 23:59 UTC on December 31, 2049.

P.title: Will we know what Dark Matter is before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The universe is thought to contain:
only around 5% of ordinary matter
25% Dark Matter
70% Dark Energy
In other words, we don't know what 95% of the universe is made of.
Presence of Dark matter is implied in a variety of astrophysical observations, including gravitational effects that cannot be explained unless more matter is present than can be seen.
Dark energy is an unknown form of energy which is hypothesized to permeate all of space, tending to accelerate the expansion of the universe. Dark energy is the most accepted hypothesis to explain the observations since the 1990s indicating that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate.
What is Dark Matter and Dark Energy? by Kurzgesagt – In a Nutshell is an approachable introduction to the topic.
The question asks whether a Nobel Prize will be awarded before 2050 for work done primarily later than 2015, and directly related to explaining what Dark Matter is, as mentioned in the prize rationale.
If the prize is awarded before 2050 the question will close retroactively to the day before prize announcement. If the prize is not awarded before 2050, the question will close the day before the Nobel Prize announcement of 2049.

para_P.title: Will the nature of Dark Matter be understood by 2050?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The universe is composed of approximately 5% ordinary matter, 25% Dark Matter, and 70% Dark Energy, leaving 95% of its composition unknown.
Dark Matter's existence is inferred from various astrophysical phenomena, such as gravitational effects unaccounted for by visible matter alone.
Dark Energy, a mysterious energy believed to fill all of space, is thought to drive the universe's accelerating expansion, a theory supported since the 1990s.
For an accessible overview, see 'What is Dark Matter and Dark Energy?' by Kurzgesagt – In a Nutshell.
The question pertains to whether a Nobel Prize will be granted before 2050 for research primarily conducted after 2015 that significantly contributes to understanding Dark Matter, as specified in the prize's rationale.
Should such a prize be awarded prior to 2050, the resolution will retroactively apply to the day before the announcement. If no prize is awarded by then, the resolution will occur the day before the 2049 Nobel Prize announcements.

P.title: Will the United States sign a Treaty on the Prohibition of Lethal Autonomous Weapons Systems before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if, by Jan 1, 2031, the United States Government formally agrees to an international treaty which purports to ban either the possession or the use of Lethal Autonomous Weapons as defined above, and is announced on the U.S. Department of State Office of Treaty Affairs or a mainstream news source or wire service (e.g. AP or New York Times), or NO otherwise.

para_P.title: By 2031, will the U.S. have entered into an international agreement banning lethal autonomous weapons systems?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as YES if the U.S. Government has officially joined an international treaty that prohibits the ownership or use of lethal autonomous weapons systems by January 1, 2031, as confirmed by the U.S. Department of State Office of Treaty Affairs or a recognized major news outlet such as the Associated Press or the New York Times. It will resolve as NO if this condition is not met.

P.title: Will EQRx get at least one drug approved by the FDA before the end of 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
From this Chemical and Engineering News article:
Venture capitalist and serial entrepreneur Alexis Borisy has founded EQRx to develop equal or better versions of innovative medicines—often called me-too drugs—and sell them at a substantial discount to competing therapies. With an initial investment of $200 million from a syndicate of investors, the biotech firm plans to put 10 new, more affordable drugs on the market in the next decade.
He plans to do that unsing technology (ibid.):
“Today, you can do a virtual screen of a billion compounds, do on-demand synthesis of all of those, and you can do it overnight in the cloud.”
Once a molecule is made, Borisy points to the potential to analyze reams of clinical data to design efficient studies that can prove a drug’s value to government groups and payers.
Combined, these technological efficiencies could bring down the cost of getting a drug onto the market—often cited as between $2 billion and $3 billion—by an order of magnitude, Borisy says. If EQRx spends, on average, $300 million to $400 million per drug, he believes the biotech firm can still be “very profitable,” even as it offers its medicines at a significant discount.
A Stat article has this to say about EQRx's plan:
Quite simply, Borisy is going to invent and develop new drugs, and sell them for less money than the competition. He calls this “a radical proposition.” In any other sector, it would just be called “business.”
To offer some counterweight, Derek Lowe (who writes probably the most famous and oldest chemistry blog, and has been working in drug discovery for decades) has this to say:
No, in case you were wondering, you cannot virtually screen a billion compounds overnight.
no, you cannot do “on-demand synthesis of all of those”, either.
I will put up $500 dollars on LongBets.com against the proposition that EQRx will produce ten drugs in the next ten years.
We will ask here about a much less ambitious goal: Will EQRx get at least one new drug approved by the FDA before the end of 2030?
If EQRx ceases to exist before 2031, this resolves negative. Exception: if the company gets bought / merges with another before it has had a drug approved by the FDA, any drug that clearly originated in EQRx and gets approved before the deadline counts.

para_P.title: By the close of 2030, will EQRx have secured FDA approval for at least one pharmaceutical product?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be resolved in the affirmative if, by the end of 2030, EQRx has successfully received FDA approval for at least one of its drugs. If EQRx is no longer operational before 2031 without having achieved this, the resolution will be negative. However, if EQRx is acquired or merges with another company and a drug originally developed by EQRx receives FDA approval before the end of 2030, it will still count towards a positive resolution.

P.title: Will Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed experience a significant leadership disruption before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A "significant leadership disruption" includes confirmed reports that Abiy has:
resigned (including the issuance of a resignation that will take effect at a later date),
lost a confidence vote,
lost an election,
formally left office,
died,
been forcibly removed from office for 10 or more consecutive days,
fled or been exiled from office for 10 or more consecutive days,
been medically incapacitated from discharging their duties for 10 or more consecutive days,
been missing (whereabouts unknown) for 10 or more consecutive days.
Resolution will be according to reliable published reports

para_P.title: Will there be a major disruption in Abiy Ahmed's role as Prime Minister of Ethiopia before 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A "major disruption" in leadership is defined as any of the following confirmed events affecting Abiy Ahmed:
- Resignation (including future-dated resignations),
- Loss of a confidence vote,
- Electoral defeat,
- Official departure from office,
- Death,
- Forced removal from office for at least 10 consecutive days,
- Exile for at least 10 consecutive days,
- Medical incapacity preventing duty performance for at least 10 consecutive days,
- Unexplained disappearance for at least 10 consecutive days.
Resolution will be based on credible published sources.

P.title: Will Reddit power user "maxwellhill" be confirmed to be Ghislaine Maxwell before 2026?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This theory will be considered confirmed if it is stated by Ghislaine Maxwell or her representatives, or reported by police, prosecutors or reliable witnesses that Maxwell either is maxwellhill specifically or that she was an active and influential Reddit user (or words to that effect).
There could also be an accumulation of evidence over time. If respectable news organisations like the New York Times, Washington Post, Guardian or Sydney Morning Herald report that Maxwell is or is likely to be maxwellhill, that will also suffice

para_P.title: By the end of 2025, will it be verified that "maxwellhill" on Reddit is actually Ghislaine Maxwell?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The claim will be deemed verified if either Ghislaine Maxwell herself, her legal representatives, law enforcement, or credible witnesses confirm that she is, or was, the Reddit user known as maxwellhill, or describe her as an influential Reddit user. Additionally, credible accumulation of evidence reported by reputable media outlets such as the New York Times, Washington Post, Guardian, or Sydney Morning Herald indicating that Maxwell is or was maxwellhill will also be sufficient for confirmation.

P.title: Will Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster be visited by a spacecraft before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster is an electric sports car that served as the dummy payload for the February 2018 Falcon Heavy test flight and became an artificial satellite of the Sun.
In August 2019, as the Roadster completed its first orbit around the Sun, Musk stated that SpaceX may one day launch a small spacecraft to catch up with the Roadster and take photographs.
Will Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster be visited by any spacecraft before 2050?
The question will resolve positively if any active spacecraft approaches the Tesla Roadster to within a distance of 10,000 kilometers before December 31st of 2049, 23:59 UTC.

para_P.title: Will a spacecraft approach Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster within 10,000 kilometers by the end of 2049?
para_P.body: Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster, launched as a dummy payload during the Falcon Heavy test flight in February 2018, orbits the Sun as an artificial satellite. In 2019, Musk suggested that SpaceX might send a spacecraft to rendezvous with the Roadster for photography purposes. This question will be resolved affirmatively if, by 23:59 UTC on December 31, 2049, any operational spacecraft comes within 10,000 kilometers of the Tesla Roadster.

P.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Will Turkey remain a continuous member of NATO until January 1, 2025?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey maintains uninterrupted membership in NATO from October 1, 2019, to January 1, 2025. It will resolve as No if Turkey is either suspended, expelled, or voluntarily withdraws from NATO at any point before January 1, 2025.
Should NATO be dissolved, or undergo such significant changes in structure or function that Metaculus administrators deem it imprudent to continue this question, it will resolve as Ambiguous

P.title: If Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, will their first 2 elected Senators both be Democrats?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the first 2 elected Senators of Puerto Rico are both members of the Democratic Party
†
, as of their date of election. It will resolve negatively if they are a member of any other party
†
, including if they are independents who caucus with Democrats.
If Puerto Rico is not a state at any time prior to January 1, 2035, or if Puerto Rico will not elect at least 2 senators by that time, this question will resolve ambiguously.
Senators must be elected by the general populace. If Senators are appointed for PR, this question will wait to resolve on the first Senators who are elected. This question will resolve for the first 2 elected senators, regardless of whether those senators are elected in the same year or in the same election.
Fine Print
†
If both elected senators are members of a Democratic Party Affiliate (for example, the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party), they will be considered Democrats for this question, assuming the Democratic Party does not endorse or support competing candidates in Puerto Rico (on or immediately prior to the general election day).
Senators will be "elected prior to 2035-01-01" if their election day is prior to 2035-01-01, regardless of when they are projected by election media, or when they take office.

para_P.title: By 2035, should Puerto Rico achieve statehood, will the initial pair of Senators elected both align with the Democratic Party?
para_P.body:
This forecast will be affirmed if the initial two Senators from Puerto Rico, upon their election, are confirmed as Democrats. It will be negated if either is affiliated with another party, including independents who caucus with Democrats. Should Puerto Rico not attain statehood by January 1, 2035, or fail to elect at least two Senators by then, the outcome will be considered ambiguous. The resolution applies solely to Senators chosen through a public election; appointed Senators do not count. The resolution concerns only the first two elected Senators, irrespective of whether their elections occur simultaneously or separately.

Clarification: Senators are considered 'elected prior to 2035-01-01' if their election occurs before this date, regardless of when they are declared winners or assume office. Senators affiliated with a Democratic Party Affiliate will be regarded as Democrats, provided the Democratic Party does not endorse competing candidates in Puerto Rico around the election date.

P.title: Longbets series: By 2030, will commercial passengers routinely fly in pilotless planes?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Craig J Mundie and Eric Schmidt summarize their reasons for taking the bet here.
If the Long Now Foundation declares Craig J Mundie the winner, this question resolves positively. If they declare Eric Schmidt the winner, this question resolves negatively.

para_P.title: Will commercial air travel commonly involve unmanned aircraft by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The debate between Craig J Mundie and Eric Schmidt is detailed here.
Should the Long Now Foundation announce Craig J Mundie as the victor, the outcome will be affirmative. If Eric Schmidt is declared the victor, the outcome will be negative.

P.title: If Biden becomes president, will there be an expansion of the Keystone Pipeline system of at least 100 km in length by the end of 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Keystone Pipeline system is an oil pipeline in Canada and the United States, beginning operations in 2010.
The fourth phase, referred to as Keystone XL, attracted opposition from environmentalists and was eventually denied a permit by the Obama administration in 2015. Under Trump, a permit was granted again, though construction has not yet started.
In May 2020, Biden claimed that if elected, he will cancel the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline.
If Biden is elected president in the 2020 election and takes office, will the Keystone Pipeline system be extended by at least 100 km between his inauguration and the end of 2024?
Only the length of pipeline built on US territory will count for this question.

para_P.title: Should Biden win the presidency, will the Keystone Pipeline system see an extension of at least 100 km by 2024's conclusion?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Keystone Pipeline, operational since 2010, spans across Canada and the U.S. The project's fourth phase, Keystone XL, faced resistance from environmental groups and was blocked by the Obama administration in 2015. It was later reauthorized under Trump, though construction has not commenced.
In May 2020, Biden announced his intention to revoke the Keystone XL permit if he wins the presidency.
Assuming Biden's victory and subsequent inauguration, will there be a minimum 100 km expansion of the Keystone Pipeline within the U.S. by the end of 2024?

P.title: Will the United States land humans on the moon again before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a mission of the United States, or any corporation incorporated in the United States, lands one or more living humans on the Moon at any time between January 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025.
The crewed landing must occur before 00:00 UTC on January 1, 2025, and at least one crew member must be a human alive at the time of landing. A successful return to Earth or any other conclusion of the mission is not necessary for a positive resolution.
A positive resolution requires that the mission is more than 50% funded by the Federal Government of the United States or by any agency thereof, or by any agency of the several States, or by any legal or natural person(s) resident (or incorporated) in the United States, or by any combination of the aforementioned entities.
A mission in which such entities contribute exactly 50% or less than 50% of the funding does not count as a US mission for the purposes of this question

para_P.title: Will the U.S. achieve a manned lunar landing before 2025?
para_P.body: This question will be affirmed if, between January 1, 2019, and January 1, 2025, the United States or any U.S.-based corporation successfully lands at least one living human on the Moon. The landing must occur before 00:00 UTC on January 1, 2025. The survival of the crew post-landing or the mission's subsequent outcomes do not influence the resolution. For a positive resolution, the mission must be primarily funded (over 50%) by the U.S. Federal Government, any U.S. state agency, or any U.S. residents or corporations, solely or in combination. Missions funded 50% or less by these entities will not qualify as U.S. missions for this query.

P.title: Will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Elon Musk's dream of a hyperloop – a pod-based transportation system that uses magnetic levitation in a near-vacuum – is coming closer to reality. Tests in the Nevada desert have achieved speeds up to 192 mph, and Musk announced in July 2017 that he had "verbal approval" for a hyperloop between New York and Washington, DC. (Though it is rather unclear what exactly this means.)
But other countries are interested too. Dubai and Russia are both developing plans. For Russia, a hyperloop could open up new areas of the country to trade with China. If, that is, lawsuits don't derail the project. In Dubai, designs for a Dubai-Abu Dhabi hyperloop network already exist.
Although implementing the hyperloop concept is far from easy, several writers have said that testing and construction should begin anyway, as the hyperloop may be the revolutionary transportation system the world desperately needs.
Will the first commercial hyperloop system be built inside of the United States?
This question will resolve as positive if the first hyperloop system to commence commercial operations is located the US rather than in Dubai, Russia, or any other country outside the US. Resolves as ambiguous if no commercial hyperloop system is operating as of 2035.
"Commerical Operations" means that people will utilize the system as transport (even if somewhat as a novelty) outside of a test setting and without signing any waivers etc.

para_P.title: Will the inaugural operational hyperloop system be established in the United States?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The concept of the hyperloop, a high-speed pod-based transport system utilizing magnetic levitation in a near-vacuum environment, is progressing towards reality. Notable advancements include tests in Nevada achieving speeds of 192 mph, and a 2017 announcement by Elon Musk about a potential hyperloop route between New York and Washington, DC, although the specifics of this approval remain vague.
Interest in hyperloop technology is global, with significant developments in Dubai and Russia. Russia views hyperloop technology as a means to enhance trade with China, while Dubai has plans for a network between Dubai and Abu Dhabi. Despite the challenges in realizing the hyperloop, there is a push for its testing and construction due to its potential to revolutionize transportation.
This question will be resolved affirmatively if the first hyperloop system to begin commercial operations is based in the US, as opposed to Dubai, Russia, or any other nation. It will resolve as ambiguous if no commercial hyperloop systems are operational by 2035.
"Commercial Operations" are defined as the use of the system by the public for transportation, beyond a test environment and without the need for waivers.

P.title: Will there be fewer Kea parrots in 2030 than in 2020?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Context
The kea is a species of large parrot in the family Nestoridae found in the forested and alpine regions of the South Island of New Zealand.
According to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species, there are roughly 4,000 live mature Kea parrots in the world.
Question and Resolution
Will there be fewer than 4,000 live mature Kea parrots, according to IUCN Red List of Threatened Species at any point in the year 2030?

para_P.title: By 2030, will the population of mature Kea parrots be less than it was in 2020?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Context
Native to the forested and alpine areas of New Zealand's South Island, the Kea is a large parrot species belonging to the Nestoridae family. As per the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species, the current population of mature Kea parrots stands at approximately 4,000.
Question and Resolution
Will the number of live mature Kea parrots drop below 4,000 at any time during the year 2030, according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species?

P.title: Will Israel recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if before 01-01-2030, reliable media sources report that Israel has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan

para_P.title: By the end of 2029, will Israel have officially recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan?
para_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by December 31, 2029, credible news outlets confirm that Israel has acknowledged the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.

P.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

para_P.title: Before 2050, will military confrontations between Taiwan and China result in at least 100 fatalities?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This forecast will be affirmed as Yes if, from January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2050, any of the following conditions are met:
At least three authoritative government sources confirm one or more incidents of gunfire or other military engagements between the armed forces or law enforcement of Taiwan and China that cumulatively result in a minimum of 100 deaths.
At least three reliable media outlets report one or more incidents of military engagement between the armed forces or law enforcement of Taiwan and China that cumulatively account for at least 100 fatalities.
The total of 100 fatalities may be accumulated over multiple separate incidents within the specified timeframe.
The forecast will be negated as No otherwise.
For this forecast, an armed conflict is defined as a dispute involving a government and/or territory where armed force is used between two parties, at least one of which is a state government, leading to an exchange of weapon fire or explosions

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

para_P.title: By 2050, will global GDP have doubled within any four-year span?
para_P.body: Resolution will be based on a reliable evaluation of global GDP in constant U.S. dollars or another universally recognized metric. The question will resolve affirmatively if there is any four-year period before 2050 during which global output doubles. It will resolve negatively if it does not, or if the resolution of the related question about whether a four-year doubling occurs before a one-year doubling is unclear.

P.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a nationalized organization?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a nationalized organization.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
University group develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

para_P.title: Will the team behind the creation of the first AGI be affiliated with a government-owned entity?
para_P.body:
This question will be affirmed if the first publicly acknowledged AGI, as per the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known.', was created by a team from a government-owned entity. If the development involves a partnership between multiple entities, such as a corporation and a university, the answer will still be affirmative. For instance, a collaboration between OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI would satisfy this condition for both entities involved.
Related questions include whether a non-profit, government project, university, or corporation developed the first AGI.

P.title: Will aerial drones deliver 100 million or more parcels in the US by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if credible estimates state that aerial drones delivered 100 million or more parcels in the United States in any year between 2021 and 2049, inclusive. Drones need not be responsible for the entire delivery chain, parcels shipped by truck to a distribution center where aerial drones complete the deliveries would qualify. The definition of a parcel will conform to the USPS definition (see the link and quote in the question background)

para_P.title: By 2050, will drones have completed the delivery of at least 100 million packages in the US?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved affirmatively if reliable sources confirm that between 2021 and 2049, drones have been used to deliver 100 million or more packages in any single year within the United States. It is not necessary for drones to handle the entire delivery process; packages transported to a distribution center by truck and then delivered by drones are included. The term 'package' adheres to the definition used by the USPS.

P.title: Will a functional Alcubierre drive-like FTL device be demonstrated before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Alcubierre drive is a speculative warp drive idea based on a solution of Einstein's field equations in general relativity as proposed by Mexican theoretical physicist Miguel Alcubierre, by which a spacecraft could achieve apparent faster-than-light travel if a configurable energy-density field lower than that of vacuum (that is, negative mass) could be created.
Rather than exceeding the speed of light within a local reference frame, a spacecraft would traverse distances by contracting space in front of it and expanding space behind it, resulting in effective faster-than-light travel. Objects cannot accelerate to the speed of light within normal spacetime; instead, the Alcubierre drive shifts space around an object so that the object would arrive at its destination more quickly than light would in normal space without breaking any physical laws.
However, there are a number of technical challenges that may mean that it is either extremely difficult or impossible to create a device that functions as Alcubierre described.
Alcubierre's original paper can be read here: The warp drive: hyper-fast travel within general relativity
Will a functional Alcubierre drive device be demonstrated before 2100?
This question will resolve as Yes if before January 1, 2100, a credible paper is published in a peer-reviewed journal that details a successful demonstration of a functioning device that works broadly in the manner that Alcubierre described, and that enables a physical object to traverse distances at faster-than-light speeds.
This demonstration must take place in 'base reality' (i.e. the universe in which the concept was originally proposed, and in which Metaculus users in January 2021 lived) rather than in any kind of simulated reality or alternative physical universe that is created or discovered after February 12, 2021.

para_P.title: Will an operational Alcubierre-style warp drive be proven to work before the year 2100?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The concept of the Alcubierre drive, proposed by Miguel Alcubierre, is based on theoretical solutions to Einstein's field equations that suggest a spacecraft could achieve faster-than-light travel by manipulating space-time around it. This involves contracting space in front of the spacecraft and expanding it behind, allowing the spacecraft to cover distances faster than light could in normal space, without violating the laws of physics.
Despite the theoretical possibility, numerous technical hurdles could render the practical creation of such a device highly challenging or even unfeasible.
Alcubierre's foundational paper is titled 'The warp drive: hyper-fast travel within general relativity.'
Will a working Alcubierre-style warp drive be demonstrated before 2100?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2100, a credible peer-reviewed journal publishes a paper that reports a successful demonstration of a device that operates in a manner similar to Alcubierre's proposal, enabling faster-than-light travel for a physical object.
The demonstration must occur in the original universe where the concept was proposed and where Metaculus users in January 2021 resided, not in any simulated or alternate reality created or discovered post-February 12, 2021.

P.title: Will any science fiction literature originally written in Spanish win a major science fiction award before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be positive if a short story, novelette, novella or novel originally written in Spanish and published by the end of 2029, in any medium, is granted one of the following awards: Hugo, Nebula, John W. Campbell, Theodore Sturgeon or Arthur C. Clarke, before the end of the year 2030.
(Note: except for the Hugo Prize, these prizes currently require a previous translation into English. The answer will be positive if and only if the work was originally written and published in Spanish).
(EN ESPAÑOL:)
¿Ganará una obra de Ciencia Ficción escrita y publicada originalmente en español hasta el año 2029 incluido alguno de los grandes premios internaciones que acreditan a los grandes autores del género?
La respuesta será SI, si un cuento corto, novela corta (en cualquiera de sus extensiones) o novela escrita en castellano y publicada hasta el año 2029, en cualquier medio, recibe uno de los siguientes premios: Hugo, Nébula, John W. Campbell, Theodore Sturgeon o Arthur C. clarke, antes del cierre del año 2030.
(Nota, en la actualidad excepto el premio Hugo al que podría acceder directamente una obra escrita en español, el resto requieren una traducción previa al inglés. La respuesta será positiva si y solo sí la obra fue escrita y publicada con anterioridad en español).

para_P.title: By the end of 2030, will a Spanish-written science fiction work have received a major international award?
para_P.body: The question will resolve positively if a science fiction work, originally composed in Spanish and published by 2029, wins one of the major awards (Hugo, Nebula, John W. Campbell, Theodore Sturgeon, or Arthur C. Clarke) by the end of 2030. The work must be a short story, novelette, novella, or novel and must have been initially published in Spanish. Note: Except for the Hugo Award, these awards generally require an English translation prior to winning, but the resolution will be affirmative only if the work was originally written and published in Spanish.

P.title: Will the next Millennium Prize Problem be solved by AI?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if the next Millennium Prize Problem is solved by AI, and NO otherwise.
The question will resolve when the next Millennium Prize Problem is announced as solved by the Clay Mathematics Institute, or, in case that is no longer possible, as soon as consensus in the mathematics community is reached that the solution is correct. The question will retroactively close on the day before the first publication of the announcement of the solution by the authors.
The question will resolve positive if most of the major novel elements of the solution were primarily discovered trough the use of AI. The contribution of humans should be limited to:
Creating the AI system.
Feeding the system with previously established knowledge.
Stating the problem in a form understandable by the AI.
Converting the solution into a form understandable by humans.
Other tasks unrelated to the core of the solution.
The AI should be understood broadly as any computation system that is not human.
Fine Print
If the triggering event is still considered unclear, then the ambiguity will be resolved based on whether at least one more similar breakthrough (including, but not limited to, other Milenium Prize problems) featuring similar use of AI follows in the 3 years following the first solution announcement. The main promise of the AI systems is their ability to increase the speed of discoveries beyond human ability, so this type of disambiguation should remain true to this question's spirit.

para_P.title: Will an AI system solve the upcoming Millennium Prize Problem?
para_P.body:
This question will be resolved as YES if an artificial intelligence (AI) system solves the next Millennium Prize Problem, and NO if not. The resolution will occur when the Clay Mathematics Institute, or a recognized consensus in the mathematics community, confirms the problem has been solved. The resolution date will be set to the day before the solution's initial public announcement.

The criteria for a YES resolution include that the AI must have primarily contributed to the key innovative aspects of the solution. Human involvement should be restricted to tasks such as developing the AI, inputting existing knowledge, formulating the problem for the AI, and translating the AI's output into human-readable form, among other non-essential tasks. The definition of AI encompasses any non-human computational system.

In cases of ambiguity regarding the resolution, the situation will be clarified if a similar AI-driven breakthrough occurs within three years after the initial announcement. This approach aligns with the expected acceleration of discovery rates through AI technology.

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

para_P.title: By 2050, will over half of the adult population in the United States possess a personal augmented reality device?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as Yes if, at any point before January 1, 2050, a reliable survey indicates that over 50% of U.S. adults have acquired any form of personal augmented reality device. For this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as a portable device primarily used for augmented reality functions, which involve displaying digital data and images superimposed on the user's real-world view, updating dynamically as the user interacts with both digital and physical environments. Devices like smartphones, which are only occasionally used for augmented reality, do not qualify. If a survey includes a significant number of non-qualifying devices, the administrators may use their discretion to choose an alternative survey, declare the results ambiguous, or apply their best judgment.

P.title: Will US Non-Overseas Contingency operations military deaths exceed 3,000 in any calendar year before 2032?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the number of military deaths across all branches of the US armed forces is greater than 3,000 in any calendar year between 2019 and 2031 (inclusive), according to the Congressional Research Service. Deaths should include all branches of the US armed forces and all active duty troops, including mobilized Reserve and Guard components. The estimate should include only "Non-Overseas Contingency Operations". Contingency Operations are defined by CRS according to
Section 101 of Title 10, United States Code, defines a contingency operation as any Secretary of Defense-designated military operation “in which members of the armed forces are or may become involved in military actions, operations, or hostilities against an enemy of the United States or against an opposing military force.
If data by CRS is not available or complete between 2019 and 2031, Metaculus may select another credible source of data, or resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

para_P.title: Before 2032, will the annual number of non-overseas contingency military fatalities in the US exceed 3,000 in any year?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as Yes if, according to the Congressional Research Service, the total number of deaths among all branches of the US military exceeds 3,000 in any single calendar year from 2019 to 2031, excluding deaths from Overseas Contingency Operations. The count includes all active duty personnel, as well as mobilized Reserve and Guard members. If the Congressional Research Service data is incomplete or unavailable, Metaculus may use another reliable source or declare the resolution ambiguous.

P.title: Will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable fo the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)

para_P.title: Will the control problem be resolved prior to the emergence of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will be settled as Yes if there is a consensus among experts that the control problem has been addressed before the first public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI is defined as having the capabilities listed in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence must be able to:
- Successfully pass a Turing test that would qualify for the Loebner Silver Prize.
- Achieve a score of 90% or higher on a comprehensive version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, such as the "Winogrande" challenge or a similar test where human performance is 90+%
- Attain a score in the 75th percentile or higher (relative to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on the full mathematics section of a standard SAT exam from around 2015-2020, using only images of the exam pages and having been trained on fewer than ten SAT exams. Training on other distinct math problem sets is allowed.
- Learn and explore all 24 rooms of the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" using just visual inputs and standard controls, within less than 100 hours of real-time play.
- Be "unified" enough to, for instance, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during video game play. This implies that the system should not be merely a collection of specialized sub-systems but a single system capable of handling multiple tasks.

P.title: Will any Member State leave the Eurozone before 2025?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Eurozone, officially called the euro area, is a monetary union of 19 of the 28 European Union (EU) member states which have adopted the euro (€) as their common currency and sole legal tender. The monetary authority of the eurozone is the Eurosystem. The euro is the second largest and second most traded currency in the global foreign exchange market after the United States dollar.
The Eurozone consists of Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Spain. Other EU states (except for Denmark and the United Kingdom) are obliged to join once they meet the criteria to do so.
No state has left, and there are no provisions to do so or to be expelled.
Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and Vatican City have formal agreements with the EU to use the euro as their official currency and issue their own coins, and Kosovo and Montenegro have adopted the euro unilaterally, but these countries do not officially form part of the Eurozone and do not have representation in the European Central Bank (ECB) or in the Eurogroup.
Will any Member State leave the Eurozone before 2025?
This question will resolve as Yes if, on or before January 1, 2025, any full Member State of the Eurozone (as of February 10, 2019) ceases to use the Euro as its official currency.
The list of Eurozone member states recognized for this question is: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Spain.
Note that this question does not apply to Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Vatican City, Kosovo, Montenegro, or any states that come to be Eurozone members after February 10, 2019; only those expressly listed in the paragraph above. This question also does not apply to the overseas territories of countries which have agreements to use the euro (Akrotiri and Dhekelia, Saint Pierre and Miquelon, the French Southern and Antarctic Lands, and Saint-Barthélemy.)
Resolution is by citation of a press release from the Government or Central Bank of any of the relevant countries, or by credible media reports in the financial press, to the effect that the relevant country actually starts the process of phasing out the Euro as its official currency before 2025, and replacing it with either an existing currency (including but not limited to the US dollar, British pound, Japanese Yen and other reserve currencies extant as of 2019) or introducing (or re-introducing) a national currency of its own. A decision to temporarily leave the Eurozone for a fixed period or until certain conditions are met shall also suffice for a positive resolution.

para_P.title: Will a Eurozone country exit the monetary union by 2025?
para_P.body:
The Eurozone, also known as the euro area, comprises 19 European Union member states that use the euro as their official currency and sole legal tender, governed by the Eurosystem. The euro ranks as the second most significant and traded currency globally, following the US dollar. The Eurozone includes Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Spain. Other EU countries are expected to adopt the euro once they meet necessary criteria, except for Denmark and the United Kingdom. There are no formal provisions for a member state to exit or be expelled from the Eurozone. Additionally, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and Vatican City use the euro through formal agreements with the EU, and Kosovo and Montenegro have unilaterally adopted the euro, but these are not considered part of the Eurozone and do not have representation in the European Central Bank or Eurogroup.
This question will be resolved affirmatively if, by January 1, 2025, any of the listed Eurozone member states ceases to use the euro as its official currency. The resolution will be based on official government or central bank press releases, or credible financial media reports, indicating that a member state has begun to phase out the euro in favor of another existing currency or a new national currency. Temporary exits or conditional withdrawals from the Eurozone will also meet the criteria for a positive resolution. This question excludes any new Eurozone members post-February 10, 2019, and does not apply to territories with special agreements to use the euro.

P.title: Will Apollo 10's Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Lunar Module flown on Apollo 10 is the only flown lunar module which didn't end up crashing into the Moon or burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
After 'dress rehearsal' testing in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module came within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine performed a burn to depletion which sent the craft into interplanetary space and the vehicle is currently in a heliocentric orbit. The location of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is unknown as of May 2019, but efforts are underway to find it.
As a unique historical artefact from the original golden age of human spaceflight, this Lunar Module would certainly make for an interesting museum exhibit.
This question asks: by 1 January 2050, will the lost ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module be recovered (i.e. located, captured, and physically transported to some location where humans have a presence at that time, such as Earth, the Moon, Mars or elsewhere) successfully?

para_P.title: By the start of 2050, will the ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module have been retrieved?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The ascent stage of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module, which uniquely did not crash into the Moon or disintegrate in Earth's atmosphere, was last seen entering a heliocentric orbit after a close approach to the lunar surface during a test mission. As of May 2019, its exact location remains unknown, though search efforts are ongoing. This module, a significant relic of early space exploration, would be a valuable addition to any space history collection.
This question seeks to determine whether, by 1 January 2050, this module will have been recovered, meaning it will have been located, secured, and transported to a human-occupied location such as Earth, the Moon, Mars, or another site.

P.title: Will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate change in the 21st century?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
From Wikipedia,
Solar radiation management (SRM) proposals are a type of climate engineering which would seek to reflect sunlight and thus reduce global warming. Proposed methods include increasing the planetary albedo, for example using stratospheric sulfate aerosols. Restorative methods have been proposed regarding the protection of natural heat reflectors like sea ice, snow and glaciers with engineering projects. [...]
Solar radiation management has certain advantages relative to emissions cuts, adaptation, and carbon dioxide removal. Its effect of counteracting climate change would be experienced very rapidly, on the order of months after implementation, whereas the effects of emissions cuts and carbon dioxide removal are delayed because the climate change that they prevent is itself delayed. Some proposed solar radiation management techniques are expected to have very low direct financial costs of implementation, relative to the expected costs of both unabated climate change and aggressive mitigation.
There remain risks, however. The most commonly cited risk is that people may be less likely support reducing carbon emissions if they knew temperatures were being adequately managed via other means. Since carbon emissions still cause ocean acidification, among other effects, we may prefer to reduce emissions instead. Another commonly cited reason for not using solar radiation management is that the effects are difficult to predict, though this claim is disputed. There is also a risk of a "termination shock" whereupon the discontinuation of solar radiation management, the Earth rapidly resumes its previous climate path, which could be hazardous.
There are many proposed types of solar radiation management: statospheric aerosol injection, marine cloud brightening, ocean sulfur cycle enhancement, literally painting surfaces with white colors and developing space mirrors to deflect solar radiation.
Will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate chage in the 21st century?
Given the multitude of approaches, an exact operationalization for large scale solar radiation management is difficult. While I could simply write a long disjunction of the above approaches, I have instead opted for this definition:
This question will resolve as Yes if the global average atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration is above 600 parts per million on January 1, 2101, and the Earth's mean surface temperatures are less than 1.5 Celsius above the pre-industrial baseline (as defined and reported by a reliable institution). If CO2 concentration remains below 600 PPM, this question will resolve as Ambiguous; if CO2 concentration is above 600 PPM and mean surface temperatures are above 1.5 Celsius, this question will resolve as No.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is some significant natural event that reduces mean surface temperatures, such as an unexpected reduction in solar radiation.

para_P.title: Will extensive solar radiation management techniques be implemented to counteract global warming within this century?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
From Wikipedia,
Solar radiation management (SRM) involves strategies aimed at reflecting sunlight to mitigate global warming. Techniques include enhancing the Earth's albedo using methods such as stratospheric sulfate aerosols and protecting natural reflectors like glaciers. SRM could quickly counteract climate change effects within months of deployment, unlike slower methods such as emissions reductions and carbon dioxide removal. However, SRM carries risks like potential reduced motivation for emissions cuts, unpredictable outcomes, and the danger of a rapid climate rebound if stopped abruptly.
Various SRM methods have been proposed, including stratospheric aerosol injection, marine cloud brightening, and the development of space mirrors.
Will extensive solar radiation management be employed to combat climate change during the 21st century?
Given the range of proposed methods, defining large-scale SRM is challenging. This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1, 2101, the global average atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration exceeds 600 parts per million and Earth's mean surface temperature increase remains below 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, as reported by a credible institution. If CO2 levels are below 600 PPM, the resolution will be Ambiguous; if CO2 exceeds 600 PPM and temperatures rise above 1.5 degrees Celsius, it will resolve as No.
This question will also resolve as Ambiguous in the event of a significant natural phenomenon that lowers mean surface temperatures, such as a substantial decrease in solar radiation.

P.title: Will a non-state actor have acquired a nuclear weapon from a state by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group who is not in a state's nuclear chain of command has possession of a nuclear weapon that was originally developed by a state and is in deployable condition at the time the state acquires it (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This may occur (for example) by sales, theft, or a state inadvertently losing control of a weapon. This will not include cases where a non-state actor independently develops a weapon (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
A non-state actor obtaining highly-enriched uranium or other weapons material is not sufficient to resolve this question positively. Additionally, dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

para_P.title: By 2030, will a non-governmental entity have obtained a nuclear weapon from a sovereign state?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be affirmed if, anytime from the opening of this question until January 1, 2030, a group or individual outside of a state's nuclear command acquires a nuclear weapon originally produced by a state, and the weapon is operational at the time of acquisition. This could happen through means such as theft, purchase, or loss of control by the state. The resolution excludes scenarios where a non-state actor develops a nuclear weapon independently, as those are covered in another question.
Acquisition of highly-enriched uranium or other nuclear materials alone does not meet the criteria for a positive resolution. Furthermore, devices such as dirty bombs, which use conventional explosives to disperse radioactive material, do not meet the definition of a nuclear weapon for this question; the weapon must utilize nuclear fission or fusion as its main source of energy.
The resolution will be based on official announcements from national governments, intelligence agencies, or recognized nuclear watchdogs. In cases of significant dispute or uncertainty regarding these criteria, the resolution may be postponed until January 1, 2035 for further clarification, or it may be deemed ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus administrators.

P.title: Will China land the next person on the Moon?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the next person to successfully land on the Moon before the resolve date is a Chinese citizen and will resolve negatively otherwise.
This question will resolve immediately prior to the time of the Moon landing itself or, if that’s not available, immediately prior to the first credible media report.
Fine Print
For a person to successfully land on the Moon, they must be alive and inside a vehicle that physically touches the Moon’s surface. Everyone in the vehicle must be alive for 15 minutes after the vehicle touches down. They are not required to perform a walk outside the vehicle. “The Moon” refers to Earth’s moon. This does not require that they leave the Moon. If the next vehicle to land on the Moon contains more than one person, the person who performs the first Moon walk will be considered first. If there is no Moon walk, all people in the landing vehicle must be citizens of China for this to resolve positively. A Chinese citizen counts toward positive resolution even if they have citizenship in another country.

para_P.title: Is the next individual to set foot on the Moon going to be from China?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be affirmed if the next human to make a successful lunar landing before the resolve date is a Chinese national, and negated otherwise.
This question will be resolved just before the lunar landing or, if not possible, just before the first reliable news report.
Fine Print
For a successful lunar landing, the individual must be alive and inside a spacecraft that physically contacts the lunar surface. All occupants of the spacecraft must remain alive for 15 minutes following touchdown. Exiting the spacecraft is not necessary for resolution. 'The Moon' refers to Earth’s moon. Departure from the Moon is not required for resolution. If the next spacecraft to land on the Moon carries multiple people, the first to exit the spacecraft and walk on the Moon will be considered the first. If no one exits, all occupants must be Chinese nationals for a positive resolution. A Chinese national is still considered for a positive resolution even if they hold citizenship in another country.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (North Korea)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

para_P.title: Will there be any fatalities in North Korea due to a nuclear detonation by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is contingent upon the occurrence of at least one offensive nuclear detonation between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. Should no such event take place globally within this timeframe, all related sub-questions will be deemed Ambiguous.
Should there be at least one offensive nuclear detonation during this period, this sub-question will resolve as Yes if there is at least one fatality within North Korea resulting directly from any nuclear detonation between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. It will resolve as No if there are no such fatalities. If the only nuclear detonations during this period occur outside the specified regions (e.g., in international waters or unlisted regions), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be a direct result of the detonation; deaths from fallout, rioting, or climate effects are excluded.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" is defined as any deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorized nuclear detonation by state or non-state actors, excluding detonations for testing or peaceful purposes.
Fine Print
Detonations claimed by a government as a test or peaceful explosion within 30 days of the event, and not disputed by credible sources, are not included. The final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful explosion is at the discretion of Metaculus Admins.
A detonation is considered "within" a country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level of that country's territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

P.title: Ragnarök Question Series: if a global climate disaster occurs by 2100, will the Earth's human population decline by 95% or more?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In an earlier question in the Ragnarök question series, I asked If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to human-made climate change, or the use of geoengineering as a deliberate large-scale intervention in the Earth’s climate system?, where a global catastrophe was defined as a 10% or more reduction in human population in 5 years or less.
If a global climate catastrophe occurs by 2100, will the Earth's human population decline by more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population?
The question resolves ambiguous if a global climate catastrophe that reduces the human population by at least 10% does not occur.
It resolves ambiguous if this catastrophe is primarily due the effects on the climate system of a nuclear war.
It resolves positive if such a catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population. It does also not matter how the Earth's population declines, this might be due to mass fatalities, or mass immigration to a different planet, as long as this decline is highly unlikely on a counterfactual Earth in which the climate disaster did not occur.
