It resolves positive if the 95% decline in population is primarily due the effects on the climate system of the use of geoengineering that has been principally motivated to mitigate climate change risks.
The question resolves negative if a global climate catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population does not fall 95% or more relative to the pre-catastrophe population at any point within 25 years of the catastrophe.

para_P.title: Ragnarök Series: Will a global climate disaster by 2100 lead to a reduction in Earth's human population by 95% or more?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Previously in the Ragnarök series, the question was posed: If a global catastrophe occurs before 2100, will it primarily result from anthropogenic climate change or geoengineering interventions in the Earth’s climate system? A global catastrophe was defined as a reduction in human population by 10% or more within five years.
Should a global climate disaster transpire by 2100, will it result in a decrease of the Earth's human population by over 95% compared to its level before the disaster?
The question will be considered ambiguous if no global climate catastrophe reducing the human population by at least 10% occurs.
It will also be ambiguous if the primary cause of such a catastrophe is the climatic impact of a nuclear war.
It resolves affirmatively if such a disaster does occur, and the global population drops to less than 5% of its pre-disaster level. The method of population decline—whether through mass deaths or significant migration to another planet—is irrelevant, provided it would be highly improbable without the climate disaster.
It also resolves affirmatively if the 95% population decline is mainly due to climate effects from geoengineering aimed at mitigating climate change risks.
The question resolves negatively if a global climate catastrophe results in at least a 10% population loss within any five-year period, but the population does not decrease by 95% or more from its pre-catastrophe level within 25 years of the event.

P.title: By January 1, 2050, will it be possible to increase a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Arguably the most important single difference between humans and all other life is the degree to which human intelligence allows for radically more complex forms of socialization, cooperation, activity and achievement. No other species in the universe (to our knowledge) has created the kind of complex civilization that humans have created, or anything close to it, and this is due to the large advantage that humans have acquired in intelligence.
The most widely-accepted tool for measuring human intelligence is the IQ test. The population average is fixed arbitrarily at 100, and the results of a population fit a Gaussian probability distribution, also known as a bell curve. Approximately two-thirds of the population score between one standard deviation below the mean and one standard deviation above the mean. About 2.5% of the population scores at or above two standard deviations above the mean, and 2.5% scores at or below two standard deviations below the mean. The difference in ability this represents is large. A person with an IQ two standard deviations below the mean is considered to have less than a 50% chance of graduating from high school, whereas a person with an IQ two standard deviations above the mean has a slightly higher IQ than the average holder of a Juris Doctor degree (an IQ of 126).
Psychometricians generally regard IQ tests as having high statistical reliability and predictive validity.
A high statistical reliability implies that although test-takers may have varying scores when taking the same test on differing occasions, and although they may have varying scores when taking different IQ tests at the same age, the scores generally agree with one another and across time.
A high predictive validity implies that the results of the test provide you useful insights into the test-taker, and IQ scores are significantly correlated with a number of important life outcomes including job performance, academic achievement, likelihood of being out of the labor force more than one month out of the year, and many others. More information is available here.
Because of the importance of human intelligence, it would arguably be highly valuable both to individuals and to humanity if it were possible to meaningfully increase it through some kind of intervention, whether medical, technological or otherwise.
By January 1, 2050, will it be possible to increase a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days?
This mean score is to be generated from three standardized IQ tests taken by a reliable test-taker giving their best effort using either the Raven's Progressive Matrices test or a similar non-verbal culture-fair test, with the post-intervention scores generated by the same method, and with the tests before and after intervention supervised and the results validated by at least three suitably qualified psychometricians independent of the persons or group responsible for the attempt.
Furthermore, the test-taker must be independent of the group or individual responsible for developing or carrying out the attempt, and the test-taker must not be a professional psychometrician, professional quizzer, or have ever been involved in the design of intelligence or other psychometric tests.
The final test score must be obtained within 30 days of the commencement of whatever intervention is utilized in the attempt to increase the test-taker's score (in order to minimize the possibility of an individual achieving such a large score increase through extensive training and practice).
Finally, the mean score for the test subject cannot initially be 2.5 standard deviations above the mean or higher, as it is unclear how reliable the IQ test is for scores above the +4.5 sigma range (i.e. after a 2 standard deviation increase on a 15 SD scale), given that these scores are exceptionally rare. Nor may the test subject initially score under 1 standard deviation of the United States mean score.
This question will resolve positively if by January 1, 2050,
30 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 3 separate tests, or
100 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 2 separate tests, or
200 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 1 separate test.

para_P.title: By the start of 2050, will we have the capability to enhance a healthy adult's IQ by two standard deviations within a month?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Human intelligence significantly surpasses that of any other known species, largely contributing to our complex societal structures and achievements. The IQ test, a highly reliable and valid measure of intelligence, sets the average score at 100, with results distributed along a bell curve. A two standard deviation increase in IQ, which places an individual well above the average, correlates with significant cognitive abilities and life outcomes.
By January 1, 2050, will it be feasible to elevate a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations within less than 30 days? This would involve a reliable increase as measured by three standardized IQ tests, such as the Raven's Progressive Matrices, administered before and after the intervention. The tests must be supervised by at least three independent psychometricians, and the test-taker should not be associated with the intervention team or have a professional background in psychometric testing. The intervention must achieve the IQ increase within 30 days to avoid gains through extensive training.
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2050, either 30, 100, or 200 healthy adults under 65 achieve this IQ increase within the specified timeframe, based on the number of tests administered (three, two, or one, respectively).

P.title: Will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
By August 2021, most of Afghanistan has fallen under the control of the Taliban, including the capital of Kabul on August 15. The last time the Taliban controlled Afghanistan, it was the location of Al Qaeda training bases and leadership that led to the 9/11 attacks on the United States and the subsequent invasion of Afghanistan by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). With the fall of Afghanistan to the Taliban, there is increased concern that it will be used as a base for terrorist attacks.
Will Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
This question will resolve positively in the event that both of the below are true, based on credible media reports:
A terrorist attack that kill at least 10 people has been conducted against a NATO nation by December 31, 2026. Such an attack must occur outside of Afghanistan.
AND
This terrorist attack was carried out by:
A member of the Afghan Taliban, or
A member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban.
Resolution will be based on credible media reports of a determination by any of the below entities:
The United States federal government
NATO
The European Union
If one or more such attacks have not been confirmed by any of the above entities, then this question will resolve negatively.
An attack will be considered "against a NATO nation" if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g. embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. A terrorist attack within a non-NATO nation that is not targeted at a NATO nation's government facility or personnel (e.g. an attack on a sports stadium in India that incidentally kills >10 NATO nationals) will not be sufficient to trigger a positive resolution.
If the attacks result in the deaths of the attackers, such as in a suicide bombing, those deaths will not count towards the resolution criteria, even if the attackers are citizens of a NATO nation.
What counts as a "terrorist organization" will be determined by the US federal government, NATO, or the European Union.
In the event that NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution.
Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

para_P.title: By 2026, will Afghanistan under Taliban rule serve as a launchpad for terrorism against NATO countries?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Since the Taliban's takeover of Kabul and most of Afghanistan by August 2021, there are fears of its use as a terrorist base similar to its role prior to the 9/11 attacks. This question will resolve positively if, by December 31, 2026, there is a terrorist attack outside Afghanistan that kills at least 10 people in a NATO country, and is carried out by either a member of the Afghan Taliban or a group supported by them, as confirmed by credible media based on statements from the US government, NATO, or the EU. The attack must target NATO nation's territory or its overseas government facilities. Attacks on non-NATO targets or incidental harm to NATO nationals will not meet the resolution criteria. The control of the Taliban over Afghanistan, defined as holding Kabul or most provincial capitals, is essential for a positive resolution. The question will resolve negatively if no such attacks are confirmed, or if NATO dissolves before any attack occurs.

P.title: Before 2032, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage.
Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. For example, deaths from a prior major version of Tesla’s self-driving car software would not be summed with deaths attributable to later versions.
To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. An example could be if an AI system autonomously driving cars caused hundreds of deaths which would have been easily avoidable for human drivers, or if an AI system overseeing a hospital system took actions to cause patient deaths as a result of misinterpreting a goal to minimise bed usage.
To be considered easily avoidable an incident must not involve human negligence. For example, if a human is expected to monitor the AI and promptly intervene, a failure to intervene resulting in death or economic damage would not be considered attributable to an AI malfunction unless the AI malfunction was such that a human could not reasonably be expected to prevent it. If, for example, the Boeing MCAS system had been an AI system and there was no possibility for the pilots to override its decision to lower the aeroplane nose, leading to a fatal crash, this would count for resolution.
Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included; for example, AIs used to target enemy combatants in war would be excluded, as well as AIs successfully performing a medical treatment as specified, despite the treatment causing harms that the doctors or designers were unaware of. An unexpected malfunction of an AI system used in war leading to collateral damage would qualify for the question to resolve as Yes.
Fine Print
A system should be considered AI if it is widely considered to be AI (e.g. by the credible media reports resolving the question). If this is not sufficiently clear for resolution, then as a secondary criterion, any system using machine learning techniques which has an agentic role in the disaster in question should count for this question.
Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output. For example, causing a power outage which leads to economic loss from affected businesses would count, while losing money in an AI-directed investment portfolio would not.
This question will resolve according to Metaculus' sole discretion.
The resolution criteria of this question were updated on May 2, 2023. See this comment for more details.

para_P.title: Will an AI-related malfunction lead to at least 100 fatalities or $1 billion in economic losses before 2032?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be resolved as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, at least three credible media sources report an incident or incidents caused by an AI malfunction resulting in either 100 or more deaths or economic damages exceeding $1 billion (in 2021 USD). Incidents can be aggregated if they stem from the same AI flaw or version. For instance, separate incidents caused by the same version of an AI software would be considered together.
An incident must involve an AI system acting in an unexpected manner to qualify. For example, an AI-driven vehicle causing numerous avoidable fatalities or an AI managing a healthcare system causing patient deaths due to misinterpreted directives would qualify. Incidents must be clearly due to AI malfunction without human negligence playing a role. For example, if a human fails to intervene in an AI error that could not have been reasonably prevented, it would count.
Deaths or damages resulting from an AI performing as intended, such as military targeting or medical procedures, do not qualify. However, unexpected malfunctions in these areas causing unintended harm would qualify.
Economic damages are considered as direct losses from physical or technological damage or from disruptions causing loss of productivity. For instance, an AI-induced power outage causing business losses would qualify, but losses from AI-managed investments would not.
This question will be resolved based on the criteria set by Metaculus, and any system recognized as AI by credible reports or, secondarily, any system employing machine learning in a significant role in the incident will be considered.
The resolution criteria for this question were updated on May 2, 2023. See this comment for more details.

P.title: By 2050, will genetic engineering techniques be available which can raise IQ by 10 points?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if by January 1, 2050, there is at least one commercially available genetic engineering technique shown to raise a patient's IQ by 10 or more points on average. This procedure must be effective on >66% of the public; an intervention focused on patients with down syndrome, for example, does not qualify. Studies from medical journals, statements by government agencies or public health officials may be used as resolution sources if Metaculus Admins find them to be credible.
A procedure can be considered "commercially available" if it is available to the general public for a total cost of less than 25% of the median household income for that nation in that year. "Genetic engineering techniques" include embryo selection, gametogenesis, gene therapy, CRISPR editing, and other forms of gene editing or artificial selection. For example in the case of embryo selection, the technique may resolve this question positively if it can select embryos with an average of >10 IQ gain over the median embryo for that patient. Adverse side effects of these procedures are irrelevant for the purposes of this question (with the exception that the patient must typically survive for at least 5 years following the procedure).
Resolution may be delayed up to 2060 to confirm the effectiveness of the genetic engineering techniques. If studies are unclear at this point, the resolution may be delayed, or resolve ambiguously at the discretion of Metaculus Admins

para_P.title: Will there be a genetic engineering method by 2050 that increases IQ by at least 10 points?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as Yes if, by January 1, 2050, there exists at least one genetic engineering method commercially available that has been proven to increase an individual's IQ by 10 points or more on average. The method must be effective for more than 66% of the general population; it cannot be limited to specific groups such as those with Down syndrome. Acceptable sources for resolution include reputable medical journals, statements from government health agencies, or public health officials, as deemed credible by Metaculus Admins. A method is deemed "commercially available" if it can be accessed by the general public for less than 25% of that year's median household income. Relevant genetic engineering techniques may include embryo selection, gametogenesis, gene therapy, CRISPR, and other gene editing or artificial selection methods. For instance, embryo selection could qualify if it selects embryos that are expected to have an average IQ increase of more than 10 points compared to the median embryo for that patient. The presence of adverse side effects does not affect the resolution of this question, except that the patient must generally survive at least five years post-procedure. Resolution may extend until 2060 to verify the effectiveness of the techniques. If the results are inconclusive by then, the resolution may be postponed or resolved ambiguously at the discretion of Metaculus Admins.

P.title: Will any part of Great Britain be under monarchy in 2075?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, on January 1, 2075, at least 1% of the population of Great Britain (the mainland island only) live in a state with a monarch as head of state

para_P.title: In 2075, will a portion of Great Britain still be governed by a monarchy?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve as Yes if, on January 1, 2075, at least 1% of the population of Great Britain (referring only to the mainland) resides under a monarchy.

P.title: When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Company valuations can take off very quickly: Apple was valued at around $100 billion in mid 2007, and so it has taken the company roughly 11 years to grow its market capitalisation by a factor of ten. However, one year before it first hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~$0.8 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question negative).
Amazon's rise was even more impressive. Amazon has grown from $100 bn to $1 trillion in just over 6 years. And one year before it hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~0.46 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question positive).
An important consideration in how to approach the AI alignment problem is the speed of the takeoff from massively subhuman AI to massively superhuman AI.
Paul Christiano suggests operationalising the takeoff takeoff speed of AI in terms of economic growth. That is, if there is a rapid transition from massively subhuman AI to massively superhuman AI, we would expect accelerated economic growth. One indicator of the rate of economic growth is the growth in company valuations.
Will the first publicly traded company to have a $10 trillion market cap be worth at least double what it was worth 1 year before reaching $10 trillion?
Resolution
This resolves when a company whose shares can be bought and sold on a stock exchange achieves a market capitalisation of $10 trillion (adjusted to 2018 prices), AND it was worth less than or equal to $5 trillion one year before (also in 2018 prices). The question will refer to Yahoo Finance's data, or any other reputable financial data service.

para_P.title: Will the first company to achieve a $10 trillion market cap have doubled its value from the previous year?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved when a publicly traded company reaches a market capitalization of $10 trillion (adjusted for 2018 prices), and it must be determined if its value was $5 trillion or less one year prior (also adjusted for 2018 prices). The assessment will rely on data from Yahoo Finance or another credible financial data source.

P.title: Will Europa be the first place humanity will discover extraterrestrial life, if it is discovered before 2045?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if humanity discovers convincing evidence of life on Europa before January 1, 2045 and does so before detecting extra terrestrial life anywhere else in the universe. If extraterrestrial life is found convincingly elsewhere prior to on Europa, this question will resolve as No. If no extraterrestrial life is found before 2045, this question will be Annulled.
Note: extraterrestrial life must be (a) living currently and (b) highly unlikely to be a result of contamination by Earth spacecraft. This leaves open the possibility of life transported from Earth via other non-human-engineered means.

para_P.title: If extraterrestrial life is confirmed before 2045, will it first be identified on Europa?
para_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if convincing evidence of extraterrestrial life is found on Europa before any other location in the universe by January 1, 2045. It will resolve as No if life is discovered first elsewhere. The question will be Annulled if no extraterrestrial life is detected by 2045. Note: The discovered life must be currently alive and not likely contaminated by Earth-origin spacecraft, though it may have arrived via natural means not involving human technology.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (Russia)

para_P.title: Will there be any fatalities in Russia due to a nuclear detonation by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is contingent upon the occurrence of at least one offensive nuclear detonation between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. Should no such detonation take place globally within this timeframe, all related sub-questions will be deemed Ambiguous.
Should there be at least one offensive nuclear detonation during this period, this sub-question will resolve as Yes if at least one fatality results from any nuclear detonation within Russia at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. It will resolve as No if there are no fatalities. If the only nuclear detonations during this period occur outside the specified regions (e.g., in international waters or unlisted regions), all related options will resolve as No.
The fatality must be directly caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; deaths resulting from fallout, rioting, or climate effects are excluded from consideration.

P.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

para_P.title: By 2030, will there be a confirmed test of a nuclear weapon exceeding 30 megatons by any country?
para_P.body: The question will resolve as YES if, by the start of 2030, credible sources report a nuclear detonation by any state with a yield greater than 30 megatons.
